item.title: ARC Raiders is the Highest Rated Multiplayer Shooter in Almost a Decade
item.content:encoded:
ARC Raiders continues to hold firm high up the leaderboards on almost every platform since being released on October 30. The third-person extraction shooter has proven to be a refreshing change of pace for many fans of the genre, introducing a post-apocalyptic landscape that encourages social interaction and collaboration rather than mindless combat.

It‚Äôs a sensational title that has proven it can hold its own against the titans of the genre, so much so that it has managed to earn high enough ratings to become the top-rated multiplayer-only shooter in almost ten years.

ARC Raiders is the Shooter of the Decade

ARC Raiders has stumped up a Metascore of 87, which is admirable for a new IP created by a relatively young studio whose debut game earned a Metascore of 80. In terms of Metacritic alone, ARC Raiders is now the highest-rated multiplayer-exclusive shooter to hit the market in almost a decade.

It‚Äôs topped only by Overwatch (2016), which earned a Metascore of 91 and has a similar operating model in that it only accommodates multiplayer gameplay.

If it weren‚Äôt for Overwatch, ARC Raiders would be lining up to be the highest-rated multiplayer-only shooter to ever be released. It‚Äôs topped in the shooter categories by games that came before, like Halo 2 (95), Gears of War (94), and Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare (94), but they‚Äôre all games that feature other modes and elements, including single-player campaigns.

With a Metascore of 87, ARC Raiders is on par with some truly heavy hitters:

  • Ghost of Tsushima
  • Subnautica
  • The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind
  • Batman: Arkham Knight
  • Forza Motorsport 6
  • Call of Duty: Black Ops
  • Halo Infinite
  • Kingdom Hearts II
  • Fallout 4
  • Silent Hill

ARC Raiders also shines in the ‚ÄòUser Score‚Äô rating on Metacritic. At the time of publishing, ARC Raiders boasted a User Score of 8.9, which is glowing. That aligns it with games like Metal Gear Solid, Max Payne, Resident Evil, Half-Life, StarCraft, A Link Between Worlds, Bloodborne, Portal 2, and Mass Effect 2, to name just a few games.

Embark Studios has created something truly special in ARC Raiders, and as the studio plans to support the game for the next ten years, it‚Äôs likely it‚Äôll be evolving for some time to come.

item.title: ‚ÄòThis is an XBOX‚Äô: God of War Creator‚Äôs Graveyard Joke Draws Criticism
item.content:encoded:
Hours ago, a user on social media uploaded an image of their father‚Äôs grave, recalling memories of being bought their first Xbox and falling in love with gaming. By way of a tribute to that, the user had placed two Xbox controllers on the grave, saying that their late father could ‚Äòplay along from up there‚Äô.

David Jaffe, the creator of God of War and Twisted Metal, quoted the post and wrote ‚ÄòThis is an XBOX‚Äô, echoing Microsoft‚Äôs recent marketing campaign and prompting many to criticize the developer for an ill-timed and inappropriate comment.

Was David Jaffe Mocking the Deceased?

The recent post on social media by David Jaffe has not been met with a positive sentiment:

Jaffe was most recently in the news for uploading a YouTube video explaining that Connie Booth, a 34-year veteran of Sony, was fired out of the blue.

Under the graveyard post on social media, Jaffe attempted to defend his position after gamers came for him, but his response just stoked the flames further:

Oh shut up, you f***ing babies. My parents are dead as well, it sucks. And even WHEN they died- my dad died on Halloween and you can BET we laughed about it- we tried to accept and grieve and mourn and at the same time we didn‚Äôt become a bunch of overly serious assholes

The comments under the post cast aspersions, and while some understood that Jaffe might have meant something different, most bagged on his timing and the nature of his comment.

One user wrote, ‚ÄòHow desperate for attention are you?‚Äô While another said, ‚ÄòJust because you made fun of your dad dying, it does not give you the right to do it to other people, you stinky loser.‚Äô

Do you think David Jaffe was in the wrong for what he said? Let me know on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: OpTic Finally Has a Release Date for The Process, and It‚Äôs Three Hours Long
item.content:encoded:
OpTic is preparing to finally release this year‚Äôs edition of The Process, a feature-length documentary detailing the ascension of OpTic Texas in this year‚Äôs Call of Duty League and Esports World Cup tournaments.

It has been a long time coming, with fans sitting on the edges of their seats eagerly awaiting the drop. It has been more than four months since OpTic Texas won back-to-back CDL Championship trophies, and mere weeks later went on to win big at the Esports World Cup.

Trust The Process

In a graphic uploaded on social media, the OpTic team revealed that The Process will be released on November 11. OpTic Roger later noted that the construction of the project was something monumental:

I genuinely appreciate the patience people have had for this project. I‚Äôve sunk a countless amount of time into this movie and it getting the extra time made a difference.

18TB of footage all condensed into a 3 hour monster of a documentary.

Excited for you all to watch

OpTic Texas won the Call of Duty League Championship in Canada in June, becoming the first team in COD esports history to claim back-to-back world titles. It came after a horrendous season that saw OpTic secure a historic losing streak, failing to secure a map win in eighteen attempts.

It was a horrific scene that had fans baulking at the squad‚Äôs prospects for the season, but a rejig of the roster seemed to turn things around when needed, and OpTic Texas stormed through the bracket at COD Champs.

I caught up with OpTic Texas in Kitchener during the Call of Duty League Championship, and Shotzzy, one of the team‚Äôs superstar players, informed me that winning at COD Champs would ‚Äòwash the year‚Äô of all the negativity.

Consider the year well and truly washed clean.

item.title: Fired Rockstar Workers To Protest Outside Take-Two‚Äôs London Office Today
item.content:encoded:
Recently, it was revealed that around thirty Rockstar Games employees were fired by the company, under claims that the workers were participating in leaks and prohibited discussions about the development of GTA 6. Those dismissed by the company insist they were let go because they were unionizing.

In a bid to rebel, the IWGB, a UK-based workers‚Äô union, has arranged a protest outside Take-Two‚Äôs London office, due to kick off today at 8 AM UK time.

All You Had to Do Was Follow The Law

In a video uploaded to social media, the IWGB Union explained the lay of the land, telling how Rockstar Games had ‚Äòbetrayed‚Äô the employees let go for unionizing.

Rockstar, makers of GTA, have crossed the red line. They‚Äôve fired over 30 members of staff, all IWGB Union members, in a blatant act of union busting. They‚Äôve done this for no other reason but to try to terrify and silence staff.

Not only is this illegal, but this is also a complete attack on workers‚Äô rights and peoples‚Äô well-being.

Instead of focusing on the development of the much-awaited GTA 6, Rockstar have chosen to take on the role of their classic game villains by breaking labor laws and firing hard-working staff making the game, betraying both workers and fans alike.

By way of a response, the IWGB has arranged a protest to take place outside Take-Two‚Äôs London office later this morning.

In a recent report, it was claimed that the employees were dismissed for leaking information about Grand Theft Auto 6 on a ‚Äòpublic forum‚Äô, but many have pointed out the coincidence that every employee let go is a member of the IWGB Union.

The situation has drawn a mixed response from social media users, with some suggesting that ‚Äòthey must have done something wrong‚Äô. Others backing the fired employees have suggested they sue or arrange a class action lawsuit against Rockstar Games and Take-Two.

Whatever the reason, the IWGB protest will go ahead this morning in London.

item.title: Resident Evil Film Set Photos Reveal Snowy Raccoon City
item.content:encoded:
Sony‚Äôs Resident Evil film looks to be taking place in Raccoon City, according to set photos. Additionally, it seems to be taking place during winter, if all the snow is an undead giveaway.

Directed by smash hit Weapons‚Äô Zach Cregger, Resident Evil is set to be the next big video game adaptation. With its release on September 18th, 2026, there‚Äôs a lot riding on the title in celebration of the game‚Äôs 30th anniversary. While we know who‚Äôs in the cast, story details have been quite surface-level. What we did know is that it wouldn‚Äôt be an adaptation, but take from the games. Well, according to new set photos of the film in Prague, it‚Äôs taking a whole city with it.

Raccoon City to Appear in Resident Evil Film, According to Set Photos

In an article from The Prague Reporter, filming has begun on the Resident Evil film in the Karlin district. The outlet was able to get photos on-set and reveals some interesting details about the shoots. For one, it seems the town will serve as Raccoon City, as one photo shows a map of the town and bus decals. Police cars with Colorado plates are also visible, indicating its version will not technically be in the Midwest. In addition, everything is covered in artificial snow, meaning the film will, in some way, take place during Winter.

The outlet also reports that action scenes involving fast cars and explosions were filmed in the area. Residents there were told that filming would take place from 3 pm to 3 am from October 29th to November 2nd. The night is a fairly common element of Resident Evil, so the film looks to go all in with it. Given its upcoming release, we could see more information revealed before the year‚Äôs end. Still, the addition of Raccoon City is sure to be of note, given that a majority of titles, like Resident Evil 2 and 3, take place there. Perhaps we‚Äôll see some familiar faces with Leon and Jill? We‚Äôll just have to wait and see.

item.title: Fired Employees Were Leaking Information, Rockstar Says
item.content:encoded:
Rockstar Games says it didn‚Äôt fire employees for attempting to form a union. Rather, the studio behind Grand Theft Auto 6 says that staff let go were done so for leaking company information.

In a new report from Bloomberg‚Äôs Jason Schreier, the employees were giving out company secrets in a forum with non-Rockstar staff. This led to more than 30 people losing their jobs.

‚ÄúLast week, we took action against a small number of individuals who were found to be distributing and discussing confidential information in a public forum, a violation of our company policies,‚Äù a Rockstar spokesperson told Schreier. ‚ÄúThis was in no way related to people‚Äôs right to join a union or engage in union activities.‚Äù

What Was The Union‚Äôs Response?

It just so happens, however, that everyone who was let go also took park in a private union chat on Discord. The only people outside of Rockstar involved in the chat, they say, were labor organizers.

The president of the Independent Workers‚Äô Union of Great Britain, Alex Marshall, said that Rockstar was simply ‚Äúafraid of hard-working staff privately discussing exercising their rights for a fairer workplace and a collective voice. Management are showing they don‚Äôt care about delays to GTA VI, and that they‚Äôre prioritizing union-busting by targeting the very people who make the game.‚Äù

Insider Gaming has reached out to Rockstar parent company Take-Two Interactive for comment on the situation. Should a response be received, it will be added to this story. In the meantime, Take-Two Interactive is preparing for its latest quarterly earnings report on November 6.

item.title: Roblox‚Äôs Grow a Garden Getting Film Adaptation
item.content:encoded:
The popular Roblox game Grow a Garden is becoming a film from Story Kitchen. Even more so, the original developers are playing a big part in its production.

As part of the massively popular Roblox game, Grow a Garden is an idle multiplayer farming simulator. Players would buy and plant many types of crops and see their garden grow, hence the game. Despite the simple concept, it reached insane player counts in 2025, even beating out Fortnite. There‚Äôs clearly demand for more Grow a Garden and, now, it‚Äôll be met on the big screen.

Story Kitchen Developing Grow a Garden Film with Original Developers

In an exclusive article from Deadline, the outlet confirmed that Roblox‚Äôs Grow a Garden is being adapted into a film. The movie is being produced by Story Kitchen, a well-known name in the adaptation landscape. Furthermore, the original creators will join the project to help with its development, acting as producers. A statement from Story Kitchen co-founders Dmitri M. Johnson and Michael Lawrence Goldberg is available on Deadline, saying,

‚ÄúGrow a Garden is exactly the kind of imaginative, heartfelt world we love to adapt,‚Äù said the duo in the statement, ‚Äúan uplifting story-world rooted in play, creativity, and community.‚Äù

Plot details and release information is not available at this time. However, a brief description of the film is available on Deadline. The film, currently in early development, will maintain the whimsical spirit of Grow a Garden and focus on nurturing and friendship. Given the simple concept, there‚Äôs a lot of room to experiment and craft something. Story Kitchen is producing almost a dozen game adaptations like Shinobi, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, Split Fiction, and Tomb Raider. Hopefully, the fruits of its labor will result in something, well, fruitful.
